chapter_content.title: Fundamentals of a computer system
learning_objectives: functions and devices of a computer system
chapter_content.learning_outcomes: After completing this chapter, students will be able to: identify and explain computer features, classify computers by type, describe all input/output devices, understand CPU functions, distinguish between memory types, recognize network components and topologies, and apply networking concepts to real scenarios.

content.text: An electronic device, which accepts or collects data, processes them according to the given instructions and produces the desired output.

items.name: Speed
items.desc: Executes more than one million instructions per second.

items.name: Accuracy
items.desc: Provides correct output when correct instructions and data are given.

items.name: Efficiency
items.desc: Never gets tired. Can work round the clock with the same level of accuracy.

items.name: Versatility
items.desc: Can be used to perform many tasks simultaneously.

items.name: Storing and Retrieving
items.desc: Used to store large number of data and information in a relatively small unit and retrieve them easily and quickly.

categories.name: Super Computers
categories.desc: Higher computing power, large size, expensive. Used for scientific/engineering functions and complex math problems (e.g., NASA, military).

categories.name: Mainframe Computers
categories.desc: Relatively less computing power and less expensive than super. Number of users get connected using terminals sharing data. Used in large scale businesses.

categories.name: Mini Computers
categories.desc: Slower, less powerful and less expensive than Mainframes. Called common purpose computers.

categories.name: Personal Computers / Micro Computers
categories.desc: Small for personal use, small memory capacity, less speedy, less expensive, consumes little electricity. Examples: Laptops, Desktops.

categories.name: Analog Computers
categories.desc: Use analog signals such as environmental parameters (speed, pressure, temperature). Examples: Speedometers, road lamps with sensors.

categories.name: Digital Computers
categories.desc: Use digital signals (electricity). Used in day-to-day life.

categories.name: Hybrid Computers
categories.desc: Combination of analog and digital. Example: ECG machine (heartbeat signal -> digital signal).

content.description: Main functions are to input data, process and store data, and produce information.

flow.Input: Data and instructions fed to computer via input device are stored in primary memory.
flow.Process: CPU uses data and instructions for processing.
flow.Output: Processed data stored in Primary Memory as info sent to output device.
flow.Storage: Data/Info to be stored sent to Secondary Storage device.
flow.Control: Control Unit sends control signals to all devices.

sections.title: Basic Components of a computer system

content.name: Keyboard
content.desc: Most common input device. 101/102 or 104/108 keys.

content.description: Brain of the computer. Consists of three main components.

components.name: Arithmetic and Logical Unit (ALU)
components.desc: Perform all mathematical and logical functions.

components.name: Control Unit (CU)
components.desc: Controls all devices of a computer system.

components.name: Memory Registers
components.desc: Temporarily stores data needed for ALU function.

sub_items.name: Random Access Memory (RAM)
sub_items.desc: Temporarily stores data. Deleted when switched off (Volatile).

sub_items.name: Read Only Memory (ROM)
sub_items.desc: Not erased when switched off (Non-volatile). Stores BIOS.

sub_items.name: Cache Memory
sub_items.desc: Faster than RAM. Acts as mediator between CPU and Primary Memory.

items.name: PS/2 Port
items.desc: Used for keyboard/mouse (Purple for keyboard, Green for mouse).

items.name: Audio Ports/Jacks
items.desc: Connects mic, speaker (Blue=Line In, Green=Line Out, Pink=Mic).

modes.name: Simplex Mode
modes.desc: Data transmitted from sender to receiver only.

modes.name: Half-duplex Mode
modes.desc: Data transmitted in one direction at a time.

modes.name: Full Duplex Mode
modes.desc: Data transmitted to both sides at same time.

categories.name: Guided / Wired
items: Fiber Optics Cable (Reflection of light, fast, expensive)

items.name: Network Interface Card (NIC)
items.desc: Has an RJ45 port, built into motherboard.

items.name: Switch/Hub
items.desc: Mediator to connect computers. Hub sends to all (congestion), Switch sends to relevant only.

items.name: Router
items.desc: Connects two or more computer networks (Gateway).

items.name: Modem
items.desc: Connects computer to internet. Translates Digital<->Analog (MOdulation-DEModulation).

content.name: LAN (Local Area Network)
content.desc: Connects computers inside a room or building (e.g., school, office).

content.name: MAN (Metropolitan Area Network)
content.desc: Combination of several LANs covering less than 16 miles (e.g., city banks).

content.name: Ring Topology
content.desc: Computers positioned in a ring, data moves circularly.

content.name: Tree Topology
content.desc: Several star topologies connected to bus backbone.

content.name: Mesh Topology
content.desc: All computers connected with each other (Internet).

sections.title: Benefits of Networking
content: Data and information can be shared between computers.
Ability to connect at any where and at any time.

sections.title: Disadvantages of Networking
content: Breakdown of network affects function of other computers.
